head.title: The Discovery of a Second Field Methane Brown Dwarf from Sloan Digital Sky Survey Commissioning Data1footnoteÂ 11footnote 1Based on observations obtained with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and the Apache Point Observatory 3.5-meter telescope, which are owned and operated by the Astrophysical Research Consortium, and with the United Kingdom Infrared Telescope.

article.h1: The Discovery of a Second Field Methane Brown Dwarf from Sloan Digital Sky Survey Commissioning Data111Based on observations obtained with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and the Apache Point Observatory 3.5-meter telescope, which are owned and operated by the Astrophysical Research Consortium, and with the United Kingdom Infrared Telescope.

div.p: We report the discovery of a second field methane brown dwarf from the commissioning data of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). The object, SDSSÂ J134646.45â€“003150.4 (SDSSÂ 1346â€“00), was selected because of its very red color and stellar appearance. Its spectrum between 0.8â€“2.5Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum is dominated by strong absorption bands of H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O and CH44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4} and closely mimics those of GlieseÂ 229B and SDSSÂ 162414.37+002915.6 (SDSSÂ 1624+00), two other known methane brown dwarfs. SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 is approximately 1.5 mag fainter than GlieseÂ 229B, suggesting that it lies about 11Â pc from the sun. The ratio of flux at 2.1Â ÂµmÂ to that at 1.27Â ÂµmÂ is larger for SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 than for GlieseÂ 229B and SDSSÂ 1624+00, which suggests that SDSSÂ 1346-00 has a slightly higher effective temperature than the others. Based on a search area of 130Â deg22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} and a detection limit of z*=19.8superscriptğ‘§19.8italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:19.8z^{*}=19.8, we estimate a space density of 0.05Â pc-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} for methane brown dwarfs with Teffâˆ¼1000similar-tosubscriptğ‘‡eff1000italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1000T_{\rm eff}\sim 1000Â K in the 40Â pc33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} volume of our search. This estimate is based on small-sample statistics and should be treated with appropriate caution.

div.p: Over the last five years, the study of brown dwarfs has evolved from a theoretical notion to a long-awaited discovery to the classification and modeling of a rapidly increasing known population. Dozens of candidate and bona fide brown dwarfs have now been identified using a variety of techniques, including coronagraphic imaging of nearby stars (Nakajima et al.Â 1994), spectroscopic tests for primordial lithium (Basri, Marcy, & Graham 1996; Rebolo et al.Â 1996), searches of young open clusters (Hambly 1998, and references therein), optical and near-infrared sky surveys (Tinney et al.Â 1998; Kirkpatrick et al.Â 1999; Strauss et al.Â 1999; Burgasser et al.Â 1999), and deep-field studies (Cuby et al.Â 1999). Until recently, the coolest known brown dwarf was GlieseÂ 229B, a companion to a nearby M1 dwarf (Nakajima et al.Â 1995). The spectrum of GlieseÂ 229B was singularly remarkable for its exhibition of Hğ»italic-HH- and Kğ¾italic-KK-band absorption features attributable to methane (Oppenheimer et al.Â 1998; Geballe et al.Â 1996). Under equilibrium conditions, methane (CH44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4}) becomes the dominant carbon-bearing molecule for Teff<1200subscriptğ‘‡eff1200italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1200T_{\rm eff}<1200Â K (Fegley & Lodders 1996; Burrows et al.Â 1997). Models of GlieseÂ 229Bâ€™s infrared spectrum indicate an effective temperature of 900â€“1000Â K for the brown dwarf (Allard et al.Â 1996; Marley et al.Â 1996; Tsuji et al.Â 1996; Leggett et al.Â 1999).

Strauss et al.Â (1999) recently reported the discovery of a GlieseÂ 229B-like brown dwarf from spectroscopic observations of a candidate identified from commissioning data of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). The optical and near-infrared spectrum of this object, SDSSpÂ J162414.37+002915.6 (hereafter SDSSÂ 1624+00), exhibits strong absorption by H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O and CH44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4} and closely mimics the spectrum of GlieseÂ 229B. Unlike GlieseÂ 229B, which is a companion to a nearby star, SDSSÂ 1624+00 is isolated in the field. Assuming that SDSSÂ 1624+00 has an effective temperature and luminosity identical to those of GlieseÂ 229B, Strauss et al.Â estimated a distance of 10 pc to SDSSÂ 1624+00.

Within three weeks of the discovery of SDSSÂ 1624+00, a second field methane brown dwarf, SDSSpÂ J134646.45â€“003150.4 (hereafter SDSSÂ 1346â€“00), was discovered from the same SDSS commissioning data. (SDSS uses J2000 coordinates, and â€œpâ€ indicates that the astrometric solution is preliminary.) Shortly thereafter, the discoveries of five more methane brown dwarfs were announced â€“ four from the Two-Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS; Burgasser et al.Â 1999) and one from the New Technology Telescope (NTT) Deep Field project (Cuby et al.Â 1999). In this Letter, we report the discovery of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00, present the first medium-resolution Jğ½italic-JJ-band spectrum of a methane brown dwarf, and comment on the space density of methane brown dwarfs in the solar neighborhood.

The Sloan Digital Sky Survey project is described in detail by Gunn & Weinberg (1995222see http://www.astro.princeton.edu/PBOOK/). Here, we briefly outline the characteristics of SDSS that are relevant to this work.

SDSS images are obtained with a very large format CCD camera (Gunn98 ) attached to a dedicated 3âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ} field of view 2.5Â m telescope333see http://www.astro.princeton.edu/PBOOK/telescop/telescop.htm at the Apache Point Observatory, New Mexico. The sky is imaged in drift-scan mode through five broa-dband filters spanning 0.33â€“1.05Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum: uâ€²superscriptğ‘¢â€²italic-u POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endu^{\prime}, gâ€²superscriptğ‘”â€²italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endg^{\prime}, râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr^{\prime}, iâ€²superscriptğ‘–â€²italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endi^{\prime}, and zâ€²superscriptğ‘§â€²italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{\prime}, with central wavelengths/effective widths of 3540Ã…/599Ã…, 4770Ã…/1379Ã…, 6222Ã…/1382Ã…, 7632Ã…/1535Ã…Â and 9049Ã…/1370Ã…, respectively (Fukugita96 ). The exposure time in each band is 54.1 s. The photometric calibration is obtained through contemporaneous observations of a large set of standard stars with an auxiliary 20â€²â€²superscript20â€²â€²NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end20^{\prime\prime} telescope444see http://www.astro.princeton.edu/PBOOK/photcal/photcal.htm at the same site. The data is processed through an automated pipeline at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, where the software performs photometric and astrometric calibrations, and finds and measures properties of all objects in the images555see http://www.astro.princeton.edu/PBOOK/datasys/datasys.htm.

To date, a number of 2.âˆ˜degreeID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . MULOP:compose POSTFIX:endID:end\fdg5-wide strips centered on the Celestial Equator have been imaged as part of the SDSS commissioning program. The region spanning right ascensions 12hsuperscript12â„NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end12^{h} and 16hâ¢30msuperscript16â„superscript30ğ‘šNUMBER:16 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:30 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end16^{h}30^{m} has been imaged twice, first in June 1998 and again in March 1999. Parts of the region not imaged in JuneÂ 1998 were imaged twice in March 1999. Because the network of primary standard stars was not fully established during commissioning, the absolute photometric calibration of these images remains uncertain at the 5% level. Cross-correlating the data from the twice-imaged region removes any uncertainty regarding the identification of faint and very red objects, especially those detected in only one bandpass. Using this technique, we identified all point sources with i*-z*>2.5superscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘§2.5italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2.5i^{*}-z^{*}>2.5, including sources detected through zâ€²superscriptğ‘§â€²italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{\prime} only. (See Â§2.2 for explanation of superscripts.) After inspecting the images of each source, we found that the two reddest sources, SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 and SDSSÂ 1624+00, were also the most credible brown dwarf candidates. SDSS 1346â€“00 was detected only in the zâ€²superscriptğ‘§â€²italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{\prime} images recorded on UT 1999 MarchÂ 20 and 22. We note that the astrometric positions of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 in the two runs are consistent with one another. FigureÂ 1 shows the finding chart for SDSSÂ 1346â€“00.

Table 1 lists the SDSS magnitudes and uncertainties for SDSSÂ 1346â€“00. We indicate the preliminary photometric measurements with asterisks, but retain the primes for the filters themselves. The SDSS magnitudes are in the AB system (Fukugita96 ) and are given as asinh values (Lupton (Gunn)). The u*superscriptğ‘¢italic-u POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endu^{*}, g*superscriptğ‘”italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endg^{*}, r*superscriptğ‘Ÿitalic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr^{*}, and i*superscriptğ‘–italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endi^{*} values all represent non-detections â€“ 5Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma detections of a point source with 1â€²â€²â€²â€²FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\prime\prime} FWHM images correspond to u*=22.3superscriptğ‘¢22.3italic-u POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:22.3u^{*}=22.3, g*=23.3superscriptğ‘”23.3italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:23.3g^{*}=23.3, r*=23.1superscriptğ‘Ÿ23.1italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:23.1r^{*}=23.1, i*=22.5superscriptğ‘–22.5italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:22.5i^{*}=22.5, and z*=20.8superscriptğ‘§20.8italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:20.8z^{*}=20.8. The two z*superscriptğ‘§italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{*} measurements for SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 agree to within 1 Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma. Its i*superscriptğ‘–italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endi^{*}â€“z*âˆ¼4similar-tosuperscriptğ‘§4italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:4z^{*}\sim 4 is consistent with the i*superscriptğ‘–italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endi^{*}â€“z*=3.77Â±0.21superscriptğ‘§plus-or-minus3.770.21italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.77 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.21z^{*}=3.77\pm 0.21 measured for SDSSÂ 1624+00 (Strauss et al.Â 1999). Note that M and L dwarfs are not expected to be redder than i*superscriptğ‘–italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endi^{*}â€“z*âˆ¼2.5similar-tosuperscriptğ‘§2.5italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2.5z^{*}\sim 2.5 (Fan2000 ).

Near-infrared photometry of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 was obtained on UT 1999 MayÂ 23 using the IRCAM 256Ã—256256256NUMBER:256 MULOP:times NUMBER:256256\times 256 InSb array and the United Kingdom Infrared Telescope (UKIRT). The plate scale was 0.â€²â€²arcsecondID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcs28 pixel-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and the exposure times at Jğ½italic-JJ, Hğ»italic-HH, and Kğ¾italic-KK were 5 min, 14 min, and 18 min, respectively. The conditions were photometric, and the seeing was 0.â€²â€²arcsecondID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcs8. The object was imaged using the standard dither technique, and the images were calibrated using observations of UKIRT faint standards (Casali92 ). The UKIRT magnitudes of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 are listed in TableÂ 1. (Vega has magnitude zero in all UKIRT bandpasses.) The J-Kğ½ğ¾italic-J ADDOP:minus italic-KJ-K and H-Kğ»ğ¾italic-H ADDOP:minus italic-KH-K colors of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 are redder by âˆ¼0.1similar-toabsent0.1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.1\sim 0.1Â mag than those of GlieseÂ 229B (Leggett99 ) and SDSSÂ 1624+00 (Strauss et al.Â 1999). The z*-Jsuperscriptğ‘§ğ½italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-Jz^{*}-J color is about the same for two SDSS methane dwarfs. SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 is fainter than GlieseÂ 229B and SDSSÂ 1624+00 by Î”â¢J=1.5Î”ğ½1.5Delta italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.5\Delta J=1.5 and Î”â¢J=0.3Î”ğ½0.3Delta italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.3\Delta J=0.3, respectively.

An optical spectrum of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 was obtained on UT 1999 MayÂ 10 using the Double Imaging Spectrograph (DIS) on the Apache Point 3.5Â m telescope. The spectra were taken using the low resolution gratings, providing a spectral coverage of 0.4â€“1.05Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum with dispersions of 6.2 Ã…Â pixel-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} on the blue side and 7.1 Ã…Â pixel-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} on the red side, and a 2.â€²â€²arcsecondID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcs0 slit. The exposure time was 30 minutes. The conditions were non-photometric, and the seeing was âˆ¼1similar-toabsent1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\sim 1.â€²â€²arcsecondID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcs5. The initial flux calibration and removal of atmospheric absorption bands were achieved through observations of the spectrophotometric standard BDabsent\,+26âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end\,{}^{\circ}2606 (F subdwarf, OkeGunn83 ) over several nights. The final flux calibration, however, was obtained by matching the optical spectrum with the near-infrared spectrum in the overlapping region near 1Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (see below).

The calibrated optical spectrum is included in Fig.Â 2. Although the spectrum is significantly noisier than that of SDSSÂ 1624+00 (Strauss et al.Â 1999), it shows similar characteristics. The spectrum rises steeply toward the near-infrared, and its shape matches the SDSS photometry well. A distinct H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O absorption band centered at âˆ¼0.94â¢Î¼similar-toabsent0.94ğœ‡RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.94 italic-mu\sim 0.94~{}\mum remains after subtraction of the telluric absorption feature at the same wavelength. No flux was detected shortward of âˆ¼0.8â¢Î¼similar-toabsent0.8ğœ‡RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.8 italic-mu\sim 0.8~{}\mum.

Spectra covering the Jğ½italic-JJ, Hğ»italic-HH, and Kğ¾italic-KK bands were obtained on the nights of UT 1999 MayÂ 23 and UT 1999 JuneÂ 2 with the facility grating spectrometer CGS4 (Mountain90 ) at UKIRT. The instument was configured with a 300 mm camera, a 40 l mm-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} grating, and a 256Ã—MULOP:times\times256 InSb array. The 1.â€²â€²arcsecondID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcs2 slit projected onto two detector pixels, providing a spectral resolving power Rğ‘…italic-RR in the range 300 to 500. The Jâ¢Hâ¢Kğ½ğ»ğ¾italic-J italic-H italic-KJHK spectral range was spanned by five overlapping spectra with the following central wavelengths and total exposure times: 0.95Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (48Â min), 1.1Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (56Â min), 1.4Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (33Â min), 1.8Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (48Â min), and 2.2Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (21Â min). The individual spectra were obtained by nodding the object 7.â€²â€²arcsecondID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcs32 (12 detector rows) along the slit. The final co-added spectrum has a resolution of 0.0025Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum across the Jğ½italic-JJ and Hğ»italic-HH bands, and 0.0050Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum in the Kğ¾italic-KK band. Spectra of Kr, Ar, and Xe lamps were used for wavelength calibration, and is accurate to â‰¤0.001â¢Î¼absent0.001ğœ‡RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.001 italic-mu\leq 0.001~{}\mum. Spectra of bright F dwarfs were obtained repeatedly throughout the observations for initial flux calibration (after removal of prominent H absorption features) and subtraction of telluric absorption lines. The individual spectra were then combined and scaled to match the near-infrared photometry. The resultant spectrum is shown in Fig.Â 2.

On UT 1999 JuneÂ 7 and JuneÂ 10, we obtained two higher resolution (150 l mm-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} grating, Râˆ¼3000similar-toR3000R RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3000{\rm R}\sim 3000) CGS4 spectra of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 over the wavelength region 1.235<Î»<1.290â¢Î¼1.235ğœ†1.290ğœ‡NUMBER:1.235 RELOP:less-than italic-lambda RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1.290 italic-mu1.235<\lambda<1.290~{}\mum. The observing technique was similar to the one described above, with a total exposure time of 52 min. This wavelength region spans the peak of the emergent energy spectrum of the brown dwarf. The inset in Fig.Â 2 shows a smoothed (by 1.5 pixel) average of the two spectra. The resolution of the smoothed spectrum is âˆ¼0.0005â¢Î¼similar-toabsent0.0005ğœ‡RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.0005 italic-mu\sim 0.0005~{}\mum, which is the highest yet reported for a cool brown dwarf. The individual spectra, including the many narrow lines at the red end of the spectrum, matched well before being combined. The error bars for the resultant spectum are âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 7% everywhere, but increase to about twice that value near 1.27â¢Î¼1.27ğœ‡NUMBER:1.27 italic-mu1.27~{}\mum, where telluric lines of O i are strong and variable. The two broad absorption features at 1.243â¢Î¼1.243ğœ‡NUMBER:1.243 italic-mu1.243~{}\mum and 1.252â¢Î¼1.252ğœ‡NUMBER:1.252 italic-mu1.252~{}\mum are due to K i (Kirkpatrick et al.Â 1993).

The 0.8â€“2.5Â ÂµmÂ spectrum of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 looks astonishingly like that of GlieseÂ 229B, as recalibrated by Leggett et al.Â (1999), and that of SDSSÂ 1624+00 (Strauss et al.Â 1999). Strong absorption bands of H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O and CH44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4} dominate the spectrum, and the absorption lines of H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O at 2.0â€“2.1Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum discussed by Geballe et al.Â (1996) are also apparent. Note that while the zero-point of GlieseÂ 229Bâ€™s spectrum is slightly uncertain due to a possible miscorrection for scattered light from GlieseÂ 229A, no such uncertainty exists for our spectrum. Flux is not detected at the bottom of the H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O band at 1.36â€“1.40Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum, but is detected in the deepest parts of the H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O bands at 1.15Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and 1.8â€“1.9Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu~{}\mum and the CH44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4} band at 2.2â€“2.5Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum.

The only significant differences between the spectrum of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 and those of GlieseÂ 229B and SDSSÂ 1624+00 are SDSSÂ 1346â€“00â€™s somewhat stronger absorption lines of K i at 1.2436Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and 1.2536Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and the slight excess of flux around 1.7Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and 2.1Â Âµm. The latter excess is also reflected in the slightly redder Jğ½italic-JJâ€“Kğ¾italic-KK and Hğ»italic-HHâ€“Kğ¾italic-KK colors of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 compared with those of SDSSÂ 1624+00 and GlieseÂ 229B. FigureÂ 3 illustrates the differences between the Kğ¾italic-KK-band spectra of these three methane brown dwarfs. Burgasser et al.Â (1999) have also noted differences in the Hğ»italic-HH-to-Kğ¾italic-KK flux ratios of the 2MASS â€œTâ€ dwarfs and GlieseÂ 229B, and they use these ratios to establish a preliminary spectral sequence for those five brown dwarfs. Following their example, we infer that SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 is somewhat warmer than SDSSÂ 1624+00 and GlieseÂ 229B. However, accurate modelling of the spectra is required to confirm and calibrate this assessment.

The widths of the K i absorption doublet (EWÂ â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 6 and 9Â Ã…, FWHM = 820Â±50plus-or-minus82050NUMBER:820 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:50820\pm 50Â kmÂ s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}) correspond to a rotation rate that greatly exceeds the escape velocity from even the most massive brown dwarf. Thus, rotational broadening alone cannot account for the width of the K i lines. As the dust-free photospheres of cool brown dwarfs are transparent in this wavelength range to depths with brightness temperatures of âˆ¼1700similar-toabsent1700RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1700\sim 1700Â K (Matthews et al.Â 1996) and pressures of âˆ¼30similar-toabsent30RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:30\sim 30 bar (Marley et al.Â 1996), the observed widths of the K i doublet are probably caused by pressure broadening. Accurate modelling of this higher-resolution spectrum should significantly constrain the gravity, temperature, and pressure profiles of cool brown dwarfs.

Although the S/N of the optical spectrum of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 is insufficient for a rigorous assessment, the overall shape of the continuum may be linked to the pressure-broadened K i lines. The optical spectrum of SDSSÂ 1346-00 is remarkably similar to those of GlieseÂ 229B (Schultz et al.Â 1998; Oppenheimer et al.Â 1998) and SDSS 1624+00 (Strauss et al.Â 1999). GlieseÂ 229Bâ€™s optical flux is lower by 1â€“2 dex than the fluxes predicted by the models of dust-free photospheres that reproduce well its near-IR spectrum (Schultz et al.Â 1998; Golimowski et al.Â 1998). Possible explanations of this large discrepancy include absorption by aerosols produced photochemically by radiation from GlieseÂ 229A (Griffith, Yelle, & Marley 1998), a warm dust layer deep in the photosphere (Tsuji, Ohnaka, & Aoki 1999), and extreme pressure-broadening of the K i doublet at 0.76â¢Î¼0.76ğœ‡NUMBER:0.76 italic-mu0.76~{}\mum (Tsuji, Ohnaka, & Aoki 1999; Burrows, Marley, & Sharp 1999). The similarity between the optical spectra of GlieseÂ 229B and the SDSS field methane dwarfs discourages the notion that photochemically induced aerosols are the absorbing agent. Absorption by warm dust or pressure-broadened K i remain viable and observationally testable hypotheses, however.

Given the similarity of the colors and spectra of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00, SDSSÂ 1624+00, and GlieseÂ 229B, it is reasonable to assume that these three brown dwarfs have similar luminosity. Using this argument and the measured distance to GlieseÂ 229B of 5.8Â pc (Hipparcos ), Strauss et al.Â (1999) estimated a distance to SDSSÂ 1624+00 of 10 pc. The apparent magnitude differences between SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 and SDSSÂ 1624+00 are Î”â¢mÎ”ğ‘šDelta italic-m\Delta{m} = +0.26 (zâ€²superscriptğ‘§â€²italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{\prime}), +0.29 (Jğ½italic-JJ), +0.28 (Hğ»italic-HH), and +0.14 (Kğ¾italic-KK). The average difference (excluding Kğ¾italic-KK) of +0.3Â mag puts SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 at a distance of 11.5Â pc. This estimate must be treated with caution, however, since the SDSSÂ 1346â€“00â€™s larger flux around 2.1Â ÂµmÂ may reflect a slightly higher temperature (and hence luminosity as the models indicate that the radii of these objects are essentially independent of the temperature or mass) than those of GlieseÂ 229B and SDSSÂ 1624+00.

The SDSS commissioning data obtained to date cover approximately 400Â deg22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, or âˆ¼1similar-toabsent1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\sim~{}1%, of the sky. To boost our confidence in the one-band detections at faint magnitudes, we have searched only the twice-imaged area of the sky for objects with z*â‰¤19.8superscriptğ‘§19.8italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:19.8z^{*}\leq 19.8 (âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 12Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma detection) and i*-z*>2.5superscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘§2.5italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2.5i^{*}-z^{*}>2.5. This strategy restricts the searched area of the survey to 130Â deg22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}. The two reddest candidates in this restricted area, SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 and SDSSÂ 1624+00, have been spectroscopically identified as methane brown dwarfs. Recognizing the danger of statistical inferences based on a sample of two objects, we estimate 635 such objects on the sky (of which âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\simÂ 1/4 will be discovered by SDSS because of its sky coverage) that satisfy our photometric-search criteria. This implies a surface density of 0.015Â deg22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}. Using our detection limit of z*=19.8superscriptğ‘§19.8italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:19.8z^{*}=19.8, our search area of 130Â deg22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, and GlieseÂ 229B as a standard candle, we estimate our search volume to be âˆ¼40similar-toabsent40RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:40\sim 40Â pc33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} and the space density of GlieseÂ 229B-like brown dwarfs to be 0.05Â pc-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}.

Our surface-density estimate is âˆ¼3similar-toabsent3RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3\sim 3 times larger than that derived by Strauss et al.Â (1999). This discrepancy is due to our reduction by 68% of the search area and the doubling of the number of detected methane dwarfs. Based on the four objects identified from 1784Â deg22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} of 2MASS, Burgasser et al.Â (1999) estimate âˆ¼90similar-toabsent90RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:90\sim 90 â€œTâ€ dwarfs on the sky brighter than a 10â¢Ïƒ10ğœNUMBER:10 italic-sigma10~{}\sigma detection limit of J=16ğ½16italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:16J=16. This number corresponds to a surface density of 0.0022Â deg-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} and a space density of âˆ¼0.01similar-toabsent0.01RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.01\sim 0.01Â pc-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. For brown dwarfs with colors like those of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00, the 2MASS detection limit is equivalent to z*â‰ˆ19.5superscriptğ‘§19.5italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:19.5z^{*}\approx 19.5, i.e., slightly brighter than our selection criterion of z*<19.8superscriptğ‘§19.8italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:19.8z^{*}<19.8. Despite the nearly equal sensitivity of 2MASS and SDSS to such brown dwarfs, our estimates of surface and space density are larger than the 2MASS estimates by factors of âˆ¼7similar-toabsent7RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:7\sim 7 and âˆ¼5similar-toabsent5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:5\sim 5, respectively. Cuby et al.Â (1999) infer a space density of 1Â pc-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} from one confirmed methane brown dwarf in the 2.â€²arcminuteID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcm3Â Ã—MULOP:times\timesÂ 2.â€²arcminuteID:start POSTFIX:start SUPERSCRIPTOP:SUPERSCRIPTOP . SUPOP:prime POSTFIX:endID:end\farcm3 NTT Deep Field. This value is âˆ¼20similar-toabsent20RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:20\sim 20 times higher than our estimate for the same type of object. The large dispersion in the SDSS, 2MASS, and NTT estimates is almost certainly a result of small-sample statistics. We look forward to the imminent routine operation of SDSS as a means of improving these very preliminary statistics.

The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) is a joint project of the University of Chicago, Fermilab, the Institute for Advanced Study, the Japan Participation Group, The Johns Hopkins University, the Max-Planck-Institute for Astronomy, Princeton University, the United States Naval Observatory, and the University of Washington. Apache Point Observatory, site of the SDSS, is operated by the Astrophysical Research Consortium. Funding for the project has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the SDSS member institutions, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the National Science Foundation, the U.S. Department of Energy, and the Ministry of Education of Japan. The SDSS Web site is http://www.sdss.org/. We also thank Karen Gloria for her expert assistance at the Apache Point Observatory. UKIRT is operated by the Joint Astronomy Centre on behalf of the U.K. Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council. We are grateful to the staff of UKIRT for its support, to A.Â J.Â Adamson for use of UKIRT Directorâ€™s time and to Tom Kerr for obtaining the medium resolution Jğ½italic-JJ-band spectrum.

img.p: Figure 1. Finding chart for SDSSÂ 1346â€“00. The panel shows a section of the zâ€²superscriptğ‘§â€²italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{\prime}-band SDSS scan obtained on UT 1999 MarchÂ 22.

Figure 2. The spectrum of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 from 0.8 to 2.5Â Âµm. The prominent molecular bands of H22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O and CH44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4} are marked. The spectra of SDSSÂ 1624+00 and GlieseÂ 229B are scaled to match the peak of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 at âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\simÂ 1.27Â ÂµmÂ and then offset for ease of comparison. The scale factors and offsets are (0.79,-ADDOP:minus-1) and (0.24,-ADDOP:minus-2), respectively. The inset shows a medium resolution (Râˆ¼3000similar-toğ‘…3000italic-R RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3000R\sim 3000) spectrum centered about the peak of the Jğ½italic-JJ-band emission. Absorption lines from the K i doublet at 1.2436Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and 1.2536Â Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum are well resolved.

Figure 3. Comparison of Kğ¾italic-KK-band spectra of SDSSÂ 1346â€“00 (solid), SDSSÂ 1624+00 (dashed), and Gliese 229B (dotted). The three spectra are normalized to the peak of the emerging flux around âˆ¼1.27similar-toabsent1.27RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1.27\sim 1.27Â ÂµmÂ and smoothed with a boxcar of 5 pixels.
